Just curious, how much time could be saved by using multiple threads in such conditions? thanks

> Just curious, how much time could be saved by using multiple threads in such conditions? thanks

Hi @lipxu , Good question,
it's interesting that with multi-thread, we convert it to CPU bound from I/O bound,
it's because ansible computes and combines hosts between inv_files on every host initialization.
That's why I just use 8 threads rather than 12/24/72 in this PR.

In my test, on a T1 testbed, this single PR reduces neighbors initialization time to ~40s from ~120s.

I have another PR https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/14246 
This PR trims the hosts in the inventory file, then ansible takes less time on single ansible_host initialization.

Combined with the trim, on a T2 topology with 72 neighbors,
The initialization reduced to ~8s from ~200s.

I don't really get the purpose of this change. What is the concern of simply run `docker start <container_name>` to start a stopped sonic-mgmt container? The existing stopped container can be started with no problem. No need to clean old stopped container.

> I don't really get the purpose of this change. What is the concern of simply run `docker start <container_name>` to start a stopped sonic-mgmt container? The existing stopped container can be started with no problem. No need to clean old stopped container.

@wangxin, on second thought I agree adding the `-s` was not necessary. The idea is to improve the error message and start the stopped container instead of erroring out. The current script tries to create a new container with the same and fails. And if a container existed before and the caller didn't pass the `-n` the current change prints a hint to start the existing container.

> Can we simply ignore the fdb entries from the IPv6 echo replies?

I don't believe there is a simple way to just ignore it.
The echo reply would cause the DUT to learn all the mac addresses used in the test (even the "fake" ones that are generated).
There is also no telltale sign from `show mac` that will indicate that a particular entry is from the echo reply. 

Even if there is a way to differentiate ipv6 echo replied fdb entries, I don't believe it will be a good idea to filter or add logic to check, as the goal of the test is to test the behaviour when the mac address is unknown. The test will be the most accurate and functionally correct if the DUT indeed does not know the mac at all.

> Can we simply ignore the fdb entries from the IPv6 echo replies?

Actually, will change it so that we disable IPv6 on the DUT side instead of disabling it on the PTF container. Disabling on PTF may cause some previously populated items to be lost.
